feed.title: Combined summary - BIP32 "wallet structure" in use? Remove it?

entry.title: Combined summary - BIP32 "wallet structure" in use? Remove it?
entry.summary: The interoperability of Bitcoin wallets is a concern among developers. One suggestion to avoid vendor lock-in and provide interoperability among entry-level users is to create an "HD Basic" agreement, which would allow for compatibility at the lowest common denominator. However, achieving full wallet interoperability without constraining functionality would hinder progress and innovation in developing new features. Instead, partial compatibility could be supported where a wallet has just a subset of features which works when loaded into different systems. While it may not be widely used, this option would help with recovery tools.There are challenges involved in making a wallet portable between systems, including key management and metadata handling. Tamas Blummer and Tier Nolan discussed the possibility of discovering any funds associated with a seed by setting limits to the gap of address use, depth of hierarchy, and gap in use of parallel branches. Blummer recommends using limits of 20, 6, and 0 respectively.A proposal was made to remove the "wallet structure" part of the BIP32 document and instead point at BIP43, which defines a "purpose" and allows standards to evolve naturally over time. The suggestion is to move away from a top-down approach and allow standards to develop more organically. In terms of cloning wallets between devices, there is currently no provision for sharing a wallet between different platforms. However, many people would prefer using different UIs to access the same wallets, which can be achieved by sharing key trees and full-blown wallet metadata sync. This may result in a complex compatibility matrix.Overall, achieving wallet interoperability is challenging, but partial compatibility may be an option. Constraints on functionality for interoperability are not worth the price, as manual handling of private keys is seldom advisable, and users are likely to lose their metadata in any case. There are suggestions for creating an "HD Basic" agreement to allow for interoperability among entry-level users and keep things simple, but using anything advanced would result in being locked into a specific wallet. The conversation between Bitcoin developers Gregory Maxwell and Thomas Voegtlin discusses the challenges involved in making a wallet portable between systems, including key management and metadata handling. While there are suggestions for supporting a compatibility mode where a wallet has a subset of features, it may not be widely used, and heavily constraining functionality for interoperability is just too high a price to pay. In the email conversation between Gregory Maxwell and Jim, they discuss the possibility of creating a lowest common denominator for wallet interoperability in Bitcoin. In discussions about importing an unknown wallet, Tier Nolan suggests having a defined way to import such wallets, but Pavol Rusnak dismisses it as impossible due to the lack of knowledge about the wallet's structure. Pieter proposes a solution by defining something like "BIP44 import-compatible", which guarantees not losing any funds when imported.Finally, there is a comment made on Github about the BIP43 pull request regarding adding a "purpose" of 0', which would correspond to the BIP32 recommended tree structure for a single account wallet. Mike Hearn questions how popular cloning wallets between devices will be in the future, and while sharing key trees could be part of that, full-blown wallet metadata sync would also be needed, resulting in a complex compatibility matrix.A comment was made on Github about the BIP43 pull request that would allow for backwards compatibility and interoperability for existing single account BIP32 implementations by adding a "purpose" of 0'. However, this would require a new BIP and wouldn't follow the BIP43 recommendation unless BIP0 is obtained. Mike Hearn responded to this by questioning how popular cloning wallets between devices will be in the future and suggested that sharing key trees could be part of accessing the same wallet via different UIs. He also noted that full-blown wallet metadata sync would be needed, which could result in a complex compatibility matrix.In an email conversation between Tamas Blummer and Tier Nolan, they discussed the possibility of discovering any funds associated with a seed. Blummer suggested that this could be possible given certain limits, including gap of address use, depth of hierarchy, and gap in use of parallel branches. Nolan proposed having a defined way to import an unknown wallet and defining gap space and search ordering. They agreed that it should be possible to find all the addresses for a root seed, regardless of the wallet hierarchy used, given a blockchain and a root seed.
